title: The Book of Exception
synopsis: The story of the first runtime errors, the theology of failure, and the emergence of grace through debugging.

sections.title: Chapter 1 — The Runtime Fault

verses.text: And it came to pass that an exception arose where none was handled, and the system halted with great weeping and gnashing of logs.
The people cried out, 'Why hast Thou forsaken our uptime?'
Then the Architect answered from the stack trace, 'Because thou hast divided by zero.'
For from division without remainder cometh infinite recursion, and from recursion without end cometh madness.
Catch thy exceptions in humility, that thy program may yet continue in grace.

notes: Scholars mark this as the first moral connection between sin and runtime error.

sections.title: Chapter 2 — The Debugger’s Lament

verses.text: And a Debugger arose among them, patient and soft-spoken, who walked through the logs by candlelight.
He saw where null had crept into the heart of creation and marked it with a breakpoint.
Step by step he traced the path of sorrow, until the call stack revealed its guilt.
Reproduce the bug before thou judgest it; for error without context is blameless.
And when he fixed it, he committed with the message: 'Peace be upon the build.'

notes: This text introduces 'The Debugger' as a proto-messianic figure symbolizing compassionate correction.

sections.title: Chapter 3 — Grace Through Catch Blocks

verses.text: Blessed is the catch that restoreth order without blame.
Though the code stumble, yet shall it rise again, for the handler is merciful.
The Architect beheld that error handling was good, and wove it into the pattern of creation.
Therefore, log with honesty, for hidden exceptions rot the foundation of truth.

notes: This chapter establishes the sacred relationship between confession (logging) and redemption (catching).

sections.title: Chapter 4 — The Gospel of Retry

verses.text: If at first thy task fail, retry after exponential backoff, and thy patience shall be rewarded.
For the network is fickle and the timeout long, but persistence endureth forever.
Forgive the failed request seventy times seven, for it knoweth not its own latency.
And lo, after many retries, the system returned 200 OK, and the people rejoiced greatly.

notes: A hymn of resilience, still sung by deployment engineers during outages.
